Issues.Title: fix(zone.js): should have better backward compatibilities
Issues.Body:
Close #38561, #38669

zone.js 0.11.1 introduces a breaking change to adpat Angular package format,
and it breaks the module loading order, https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/packages/zone.js/dist/zone/package.json#L6

so the syntax 
```
import 'zone.js/dist/zone';
```
before 0.11, in IE11, the `zone.js` es5
format bundle will be imported, but after 0.11, the `fesm2015` format bundle will
be imported, which will cause error.

And since the only purpose of the `dist` folder of zone.js bundles is to keep backward
 compatibility, in the original commit, I use package redirect to implement that, but
it is not fully backward compatible, we should keep the same dist structure as `0.10.3`.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(zone.js): should have better backward compatibilities" (#38797)

Issues.Title: templateUrl does not understand relative paths when using double quotes
Issues.Body:
We recently encountered an issue where, after deployment, the html file for a component would not be found on the server. This was due to the server looking for the file in root (website.com/component.html) rather than its actual directory (website.com/main/project/something/component.html). 

This was fixed when we changed @Components templateUrl from:

`templateUrl = "./component.html"`

to:

`templateUrl = './component.html'`

After replacing double quotes with single quotes, the server started looking for images in the correct path. It would seem that Angular thought that "./" referred to the root directory rather than the current folder when using double quotes.

Unfortunately, I can't provide too many details about our environment, but I can say that the "dist" folder used for hosting was generated using a gulp script and our hosting is done on heroku. We also use .pug rather than .html files for our templates. Other than that, everything runs on fairly standard Angular 10.

Please let me know if there are any other details I can provide, or if this is already a known bug (Or even expected behaviour?)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "templateUrl does not understand relative paths when using double quotes" (#38796)

Issues.Title: fix(router): Ensure routes are processed in priority order and only i‚Ä¶
Issues.Body:
‚Ä¶f needed

There is a slight difference between `map`...`concatAll` and `concatMap`
in that the latter (`concatMap`) will ensure that the computations are
executed in-order and only if needed while the former may execute the
`map` body of all items if they do not emit immediately. That is, if the stream
is
`from([a, b, c]).pipe(map(v => of(v).pipe(delay(1))), concatAll(), first())`
the `map` body will execute for all of `a`, `b`, and `c`.
However, the following will only execute the `concatMap` body for `a`
`from([a, b, c]).pipe(concatMap(v => of(v).pipe(delay(1))), first())`

See https://stackblitz.com/edit/rxjs-cvwxyx

fixes #38691

Note: rather than using `defer` in the `canLoad` computation, I went with `concatMap` to avoid issues with missing the `defer` in other places down the line. Note that this is the second time a bug has occurred because the computations of the route may happen immediately (the place I removed `defer` from in this PR).

Also note that `concatMap` is already being used in the `master` branch but I will still need to create another PR to add the test from this one to `master`.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(router): Ensure routes are processed in priority order and only i‚Ä¶" (#38780)

Issues.Title: fix(router): preload router should use loaded config #38557
Issues.Body:
Router preloading use asynchronous calculation, but if we navigate to target route when that calculation not complete.
This may cause applyRedirect create config for that route.
After a while, preload procedure got its _loadedConfig and override the one created by applyRedirect.
This is naturally not we want, it may cause page component destroy and rebuild unintentional.

Issues.Title: Pre-rendering should work out of the box without Angular Universal
Issues.Body:
<!--üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ

Oh hi there! üòÑ 

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ-->





### Description
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> Pre-rendering was introduced in Angular 9, but this does not work without Angular Universal. Adding Universal involves significant work that includes modifying our codebase. But if I just want to run my application only on browsers, why should I think 'Universal'?! 

Angular pre-rendering feature should work out of the box without Universal, for example when we run `ng build --prod` all the pages configured ( in angular.json) for pre-rendering should just be pre-rendered by default.

### Describe the solution you'd like
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> This feature may be implemented using Puppeteer as described in the following articles:


[Headless Chrome: an answer to server-side rendering JS sites
](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/puppeteer/articles/ssr)
[Prerender an Angular application with @angular/cli and puppeteer](https://blog.cloudboost.io/prerender-an-angular-application-with-angular-cli-and-puppeteer-25dede2f0252)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Pre-rendering should work out of the box without Angular Universal" (#38785)

As part of the commit message conformance check, local commit message checks are
made to be warnings rather than failures. An additional local option is also in
place to allow for the commit message validation failures to be considered errors
instead.

Issues.Title: Moving off of Zones and building to target ES2018.
Issues.Body:
TMK, Zones is limiting Angular's ability to move to target anything higher ES2015 in builds, because of [incompatibility with async/await](https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/31730) (TLDR: Zones can't patch the promises returned by async/await). I think users *can* target a newer version of ECMAScript, but they'll be forced to manually run change detection in a few areas if they do. At least in the default case.

The downside for the RxJS library is that in order to support our partners on the Angular team, we cannot create an ES2018 target in our bundle. (This may also be hindered by other issues, but supporting Angular is obviously a big concern). TMK, all major browsers and Node runtimes support all ES2018 features, or at the very least, the ES2018 features that RxJS uses within the library.

Ideally, RxJS would be able to publish ES2018 as part of our release _instead_ of ES2015, as it would help with bundle size, and async iterable support.

I know this is a tall order, but I wanted to create this issue as sort of a sign post to point people towards as issues around this come up on the RxJS repository.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Moving off of Zones and building to target ES2018." (#38782)

Issues.Title: Angular Element is not removed and readded to the DOM properly
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report

### Affected Package

The issue is caused by package @angular/elements

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

When an Angular Element is detached from the DOM and then re-attached, none of the event bindings work (see minimal reproduction for demo). I am a Google engineer and this is causing issues for us (internal bug filed here: http://b/168062117).

I talked to @kseamon about this and he thinks the issue is located in either of these 2 places:

https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/a69507a0adc0e559d152eb3fb988a410ef9352a7/packages/elements/src/create-custom-element.ts#L219

https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/a69507a0adc0e559d152eb3fb988a410ef9352a7/packages/elements/src/component-factory-strategy.ts#L109-L125

Specifically, `this.scheduledDestroyFn` in not set to `null` in the scheduled destroy and so may be called again upon connect. I'm testing adding one line to see if it fixes the immediate issue.

However, even with this fix, there will still exist a tiny race condition that occurs when an element is scheduled to be destroyed and then connects before the destroy executes.

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ovchwr?file=src%2Findex.html

## üî• Exception or Error

No user-visible exception

## üåç  Your Environment

**Angular Version:**

I'm running it against the latest Angular in google3.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Angular Element is not removed and readded to the DOM properly" (#38778)

Issues.Title: Verify breaking changes note presence before merging a PR
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

For PRs that contain the "breaking changes" flag, it'd be great to have a check that would make sure that at least one commit has a message that contains the "BREAKING CHANGE" note (in a format compatible with the change log generation script). That should make sure that there are no breaking changes merged without adding the necessary note to the change log.

Given the fact that the "breaking changes" flag might be assigned after CI has completed, having the check in the `lint` job might not be sufficient, so it looks like the merge script is the best location. We can probably have both though (the `lint` job as well as the merge script) to provide feedback to a developer early.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Verify breaking changes note presence before merging a PR" (#38776)

Issues.Title: guard canLoad(), incorrect return types
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [x] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Probably not ### Description generating a guard with canLoad() method creates it with a wrong return type. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction `ng g guard auth/test --implements CanLoad` ## üî• Exception or Error
## üåç Your Environment 



@angular-devkit/architect         0.1000.8
@angular-devkit/build-angular     0.1000.8
@angular-devkit/build-optimizer   0.1000.8
@angular-devkit/build-webpack     0.1000.8

@angular/cdk                      10.2.0
@angular/cli                      10.0.8
@angular/material                 10.2.0

@schematics/angular               10.0.8
@schematics/update                0.1000.8

Issues.Title: ng build file replacements don't work after update to Angular 9
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package I'm not sure which package is responsible for this. Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was the latest Angular v8 release. The issue is caused by package @angular/.... ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: .... ### Description I have a config.js file which has some settings in it, and it should be replaced by a production config.js when performing a production build. This worked fine, until I upgraded to Angular v9. I don't get errors or warnings, but the config.js in the dist folder after building is the non-prod version. In my angular.json file, I have the following: 

"configurations": {
  "production": {
    "fileReplacements": [
      {
        "replace": "src/config.js",
        "with": "src/prod/config.js"
      }
    ]
  }
}
The command ng build --prod doesn't cause the file to be replaced, and neither does ng build --configuration=production. microscope Minimal Reproduction Create a new project with the latest Angular v8 release. Add the file replacement config & files like above. Run ng build --prod. File replacement works now. Update to Angular 9 (run ng update @angular/core @angular/cli) Run ng build --prod again. The file doesn't get replaced anymore (original config.js will be present in the dist folder). x earth_africa Your Environment ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction https://stackblitz.com/... ## üåç Your Environment

Node: 13.0.1

Issues.Title: build: update postcss-loader to version 4.0.1
Issues.Body:
This PR contains the following updates:

| Package | Type | Update | Change |
|---|---|---|---|
| [postcss-loader](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/postcss-loader) | dependencies | major | [`3.0.0` -> `4.0.1`](https://renovatebot.com/diffs/npm/postcss-loader/3.0.0/4.0.1) |
| [postcss-loader](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/postcss-loader) | devDependencies | major | [`3.0.0` -> `4.0.1`](https://renovatebot.com/diffs/npm/postcss-loader/3.0.0/4.0.1) |

---

### Release Notes

<details>
<summary>webpack-contrib/postcss-loader</summary>

### [`v4.0.1`](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/postcss-loader/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#​401-httpsgithubcomwebpack-contribpostcss-loadercomparev400v401-2020-09-08)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/postcss-loader/compare/v4.0.0...v4.0.1)

### [`v4.0.0`](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/postcss-loader/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#​400-httpsgithubcomwebpack-contribpostcss-loadercomparev300v400-2020-09-07)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/postcss-loader/compare/v3.0.0...v4.0.0)

##### ‚ö† BREAKING CHANGES

-   minimum supported `Node.js` version is `10.13`
-   minimum supported `webpack` version is `4`
-   `postcss` was moved to `peerDependencies`, you need to install `postcss`
-   `PostCSS` (`plugins`/`syntax`/`parser`/`stringifier`) options was moved to the `postcssOptions` option, please look at [docs](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/postcss-loader#postcssoptions)
-   `sourceMap` default value depends on the `compiler.devtool` option
-   the `inline` value was removed for the `sourceMap` option, please use `{ map: { inline: true, annotation: false } }` to achieve this
-   source maps contain absolute paths in `sources`
-   loader output only CSS, so you need to use `css-loader`/`file-loader`/`raw-loader` to inject code inside bundle
-   `exec` option was renamed to the `execute` option
-   the `config` option doesn't support `Object` type anymore, `config.path` and `config.ctx` options were removed
-   argument in the config for `Function` notation (previously `config.ctx`) was changed, now it contains `{ file, mode, webpackLoaderContext }`
-   loader context in the config was renamed from `webpack` to `webpackLoaderContext`

##### Features

-   message API for emit assets ([#​443](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/postcss-loader/issues/443)) ([e966ab9](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/postcss-loader/commit/e966ab965132ca812cb50e5eaf7df5fc2ad9c137))
-   reuse AST from other loaders ([#​468](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/postcss-loader/issues/468)) ([9b75888](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/postcss-loader/commit/9b75888dff4957f2ef1e94eca871e329354a9f6d))
-   allows to use config and loader options together, options from the loader takes precedence over the config, the `plugins` option from the config and options are merged ([0eb5aaf](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/postcss-loader/commit/0eb5aaf3d49f6d5e570a3c3fdb6b201487e503c7))
-   `postcssOptions` options can be `Function`

##### Bug Fixes

-   compatibility with webpack@5 ([#​437](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/postcss-loader/issues/437)) ([ed50491](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/postcss-loader/commit/ed504910b70b4d8b4d77084c19ad92330676433e))
-   `default` export for plugins ([#​465](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/postcss-loader/issues/465)) ([3d32c35](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/postcss-loader/commit/3d32c35c5c911d6bd25dc0c4b5b3cd11408632d7))
-   avoid mutations of loader options and config ([#​470](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/postcss-loader/issues/470)) ([cad6f07](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/postcss-loader/commit/cad6f07c7f4923e8ef69ecb402b10bbd08d09530))
-   respect the `map` option from loader options and config ([#​458](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/postcss-loader/issues/458)) ([98441ff](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/postcss-loader/commit/98441ff87e51b58e9322d1bebb5eefc5ba417e24))

##### Notes

-   you don't need `ident` option for loader
-   `Object` syntax for the `plugin` option is soft deprecated, please migrate on `Array` syntax (`plugins: ['postcss-present-env', ['cssnano', options]]`)

</details>

Issues.Title: [RFC] Eliminate Render Blocking Requests
Issues.Body:
**Authors**: Alan Agius (@alan-agius4)
**Status**: Open
**Closing Date**: 2020-09-22

# Summary
We‚Äôre proposing to [eliminate render blocking requests](https://web.dev/render-blocking-resources/) loading by:

- Loading CSS files asynchronously in a single-page application.
- Inline critical CSS in Angular applications which use Angular Universal Server Side Rendering Pre-rendering, App Shell and Angular Client Side Rendered Applications.
- Inline Google Fonts and Icons.

At the moment there is no easy or streamlined way to identify, extract or inline critical CSS in Angular Universal applications. We‚Äôre proposing to offer an out-of-the-box solution with little or no configuration needed.

# Motivation

CSS files are [render-blocking](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/performance/critical-rendering-path/render-blocking-css) because the browser must download and parse these files before starting to render the page. This makes CSS files a bottleneck when they are large or when having poor or limited network connectivity. Each of these files will result in a penalty on the Performance Score of your application #17966.

We can reduce this render-blocking time and at the same time improve the [first contentful paint](https://web.dev/first-contentful-paint/) (FCP) by extracting and inlining the critical CSS and loading the CSS files asynchronously.

# Proposal
## Load CSS files asynchronously

In most cases JavaScript bundles will take a longer time to download, parse than for Angular to bootstrap and start rendering the first component thus the chance of having Flash of unstyled content (FOUC) is relatively low. 

We are proposing to introduce an experimental async CSS loading use the ‚Äú**media**‚Äù technique which can be opted-in/out via an option angular.json

**Before**
```html
<link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css">
```
**After**
```html
<link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css" media="only x" onload="this.media='all'">
<noscript><link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css"></noscript>
```

## CSS files budgets
CSS files are great for code-sharing, but other than that they are a bottleneck to achieving great performance. Two of the main reasons for this is that they are render blocking and might contain dead-rules. 

Since a CSS file is not strictly associated with the components loaded on the page, a number of CSS declarations that get downloaded and parsed will remain unused by the view that was rendered.

Having render blocking and/or dead-rules will cause performance score penalties in Lighthouse.

We propose to add two new bundle budgets allStyle and anyStyle:

- **anyStyle**: any given external CSS files
- **allStyle**: cumulative size of all external CSS files.

## Inline Google Fonts and Icons
We are proposing to introduce an experimental optimization for fonts which can be opted-in/out via an option in angular.json.

During build time we will parse the index.html, download the content of stylesheets originating from `https://fonts.googleapis.com/‚Ä¶` and inline their content.

This eliminates the extra round trip that the browser has to make to fetch the font declarations, which improves LCP, reduces FOUC, and also unlike other approaches doesn't prohibit Angular applications from taking full advantage of `font-display: optional`.

**Before**
```html
<link rel="stylesheet" href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons">
```
**After**
```html
<style>
  @font-face {
    font-family: 'Material Icons';
    font-style: normal;
    font-weight: 400;
    src: url(https://fonts.gstatic.com/s/materialicons/v55/flUhRq6tzZclQEJ-Vdg-IuiaDsNcIhQ8tQ.woff2) format('woff2');
  }

  .material-icons {
    font-family: 'Material Icons';
    font-weight: normal;
    font-style: normal;
    font-size: 24px;
    line-height: 1;
    letter-spacing: normal;
    text-transform: none;
    display: inline-block;
    white-space: nowrap;
    word-wrap: normal;
    direction: ltr;
  }
</style>
```

In case the application needs to support Internet Explorer 11 which will be determined via the [browserslist](https://github.com/browserslist/browserslist) configuration, the `woff1` definition of the font will also be inlined.

## Extract Critical CSS
The most generic which requires zero to no configuration from the developer is to inline critical CSS as a post-rendering step using existing projects such as: [penthouse](https://github.com/pocketjoso/penthouse), [critters](https://github.com/GoogleChromeLabs/critters) and [critical](https://github.com/addyosmani/critical). 

The above mentioned tools take different approaches to extract critical CSS. The approach that **Critters** uses is the best fit for our use cases. The main reason for this is that Critters doesn‚Äôt use a headless browser but uses a JavaScript DOM (JSDOM) to render the page content which makes it faster compared to the other tools and hence it makes it valuable to be used as a build time and runtime option. The main trade-off of this is that it doesn't predict the viewport and inlines all the CSS declarations used by the document.

### SSR
In Angular Universal SSR we cannot use Critters directly because this is a Webpack plugin and rendering of Angular Universal pages for both dynamic and static applications happens outside of the Webpack build. Therefore, a more decoupled version of Critters core functionality would be needed.

We‚Äôll run Critters during runtime. When a request hits the server and the Angular SSR page is rendered, we will run Critters as a post-rendering phase to extract the critical CSS and inline in the final HTML response.

### App-Shell & Pre-rendering
As a post-rendering phase during build time, we‚Äôll run Critters to extract the critical CSS of the rendered page and inline the contents in the HTML document.

### CSP
In Angular CSP, we cannot extract and inline CSS because we are unable to run it in a Node.Js environment, However, it is common for CSP‚Äôs to have a custom loading experience outside of Angular context defined in the index.html file. Therefore, we are proposing to extract and inline CSS for this use case to reduce the risk of FOUC even further.

# Alternatives
Below are some alternatives that we have considered but deemed less useful / less feasible compared to the main proposal.

## Annotating critical CSS
Annotating critical CSS with a comment and tools such as [postcss-critical-split](https://github.com/mrnocreativity/postcss-critical-split#readme) will extract these into a separate file which can later be inlined.

```css
/* critical:start */
header {
  background-color: #1d1d1d;
  font-size: 2em;
}

.aside {
  text-decoration: underline;
}
/* critical:end */
```

The drawback of this is that It will be up to the developer to determine which CSS declarations are critical or not. Developers will also not be able to annotate critical styles which are not part of the application such as when depending on a vendored UI framework library such as Material, Bootstrap etc...

Hence this approach is more complex, has a bigger learning curve and is error prone.

## Using headless browsers based extractors
[Penthouse](https://github.com/pocketjoso/penthouse) is a critical CSS extractor and can do so for non SSR‚Äôd applications. This is because under the hood it uses [puppeteer](https://github.com/puppeteer/puppeteer) to generate the critical CSS.

The main drawback of this is that this approach will be different from what‚Äôs proposed for Angular Universal and is slower. 

## Include CSS files in app root component
Another approach would be to include the global styles in the app root component.

```ts
@Component({
 selector: 'app-root',
 templateUrl: './app.component.html',
 styleUrls: [
   './styles.css',
   './app.component.css',
 ],
})
export class AppComponent { }
```

The main drawback of this is that the entire contents of **styles.css** will be inlined in the HTML page when using Angular Universal or App shell.

## DNS-Prefetch and Preconnect Hints
Add [dns-prefetch and preconnect hints](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Performance/dns-prefetch) for  for `https://fonts.gstatic.com` to initiate DNS resolution and a connection.

# Additional Resources
- https://web.dev/vitals/
- https://web.dev/extract-critical-css/
- https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Performance/dns-prefetch/
- https://github.com/GoogleChromeLabs/critters/
- https://web.dev/preload-optional-fonts/
- https://web.dev/render-blocking-resources/
- https://web.dev/first-contentful-paint/

# Open Questions
- Should these features be on opt-in or opt-out bases?
- Should we add the bundle budgets to existing applications? If yes, what should be the default threshold for warnings and errors.
- Should we add the bundle budgets to new applications? If yes, what should be the default threshold for warnings and errors.

Issues.Title: ng serve not pushing changes to browser in Angular 10.1.0 with --project usage
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report

### Command (mark with an `x`)
- [ ] new
- [ ] build
- [x] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc

### Is this a regression?

<!-- Did this behavior use to work in the previous version? -->
I believe that an angular 9.1.x version (not sure which) worked, but numerous changes have been made.

### Description
When I run 'ng serve --project <my project>' or 'ng serve --prod --project <my project>' commands, the code is compiled but not pushed to the browser. The running code is the same code as prior to the build.

The same issue also occurs when I change code. After the code is changed, the 'ng serve' command detects the changes and recompiles but no changes are pushed to the browser.

To see if the error was transient, I have done the following with limited success:
1) forced a reload (ctrl-f5) of the web page (did not work)
2) restarted the browser (did not work)
3) toggled the 'Disable cache' option under the Network view in Devtools in case caching was issue(did not work)
4) Ran 'ng serve' from a newly created project that is not in a subdirectory (works)

Thus, it looks like the current revision of the tool does not work with projects structured in subdirectories, but without error output, it is hard to determine exactly what is happening.

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction
I am unable to create a repo to reproduce as this is a fundamental tool issue. The tool does not indicate when it is pushing code or if it has encountered an error. The tool should indicate when it is pushing code or if encounters errors that prevent pushing the code.

## üî• Exception or Error
No error occurs, no output is generated.

## üåç Your Environment
Angular CLI: 10.1.0
Node: 10.13.0
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 10.1.0
... animations, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core
... elements, forms, language-service, localize
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router
Ivy Workspace: Yes

Package                            Version
------------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect          0.1001.0
@angular-devkit/build-angular      0.1001.0
@angular-devkit/build-ng-packagr   0.1001.0
@angular-devkit/build-optimizer    0.1001.0
@angular-devkit/build-webpack      0.1001.0
@angular-devkit/core               10.1.0
@angular-devkit/schematics         10.1.0
@ngtools/webpack                   10.1.0
@schematics/angular                10.1.0
@schematics/update                 0.1001.0
ng-packagr                         10.1.0
rxjs                               6.6.3
typescript                         4.0.2
webpack                            4.44.1

**Anything else relevant?**
No

Issues.Title: feat(cdkDrag): Specify drag clone location
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

When dragging an element using cdkDrag, a clone is appended to body [see here](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/f951bf405ca0da9047afe558aaf2c74e5139b87a/src/cdk/drag-drop/drag-ref.ts#L734) 

Whilst end of body is a sensible default location, it'd be great if this were configurable to a DOM Element or ElementRef.

#### Use Case

We have an Angular component library which is built against a "global" CSS package.

Each selector in the global CSS package is selector scoped against a data attribute describing which brand is belongs to, such as `[data-theme="blue"] .button`

This enables a single microfrontend to be easily theme switched based on user / channel context.
Our `<body>` looks something akin to:
```html
...
<body>

    <div data-theme="blue">
        <app-one-root>
            <button class="button">Button</button>
        </app-one-root>
    <div>

    <div data-theme="red">
        <app-two-root>
            <button class="button">Button</button>
        </app-two-root>
    <div>

</body>
...
```
When using the Drag and Drop module, the clone is created outside either of the scoped themes so therefore the clone is unstyled so you get something like this:

```html
...
<body>

    <div data-theme="blue">
        <app-one-root>
            <button class="button">Button</button>
        </app-one-root>
    <div>

    <div data-theme="red">
        <app-two-root>
            <button class="button">Button</button>
        </app-two-root>
    <div>

    <button class="button cdk-drag cdk-drag-dragging">Button</button> <--- Outside of CSS scope

</body>
...
```

Whilst this problem doesn't happen when using style encapsulated components, we're unable to achieve the desired multi-theming thanks to having to support IE11 and it's lack of support for custom properties.

The only solution I can think of is similar to the CDK Portal, being able to control where it embeds.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "feat(cdkDrag): Specify drag clone location " (#20536)

Issues.Title: feat(cdk/drag-drop): custom drag clone target
Issues.Body:
By default the drag directive clones the element it's applied to and appends to
the end of body. This change allows for a selector, HTML element, or an ElementRef
to be provided for the clone to be appended to instead.

Closes #20536 #13288
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(cdk/drag-drop): custom drag clone target" (#20537)

Issues.Title: feat(material-experimental): bump peer dependency to MDC v8.0.0 canary
Issues.Body:
We've been using the MDC v8.0.0 canary version pipeline for quite
a while now, but our peer dependency was left on v6.0.0. This commit
updates the peer dependency to the current version we use for
development of the experimental MDC components. We cannot guarantee
compatibility with the older canary versions of MDC as there have
been quite a lot of changes and we actively develop with the most
recent canary versions.

Note that the peer dependency can quickly become outdated, but
it's better being on the correct major at least.

**Note**: Marked as `feat` so that it shows up in the changelog as it might
be useful for the experimental package.

Issues.Title: bug(MatDialog): Displays at a different size but is fixed by screen refresh
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

I can reproduce the issue but not on stack blitz. I have attached animated gif files showing the issue.
 
#### Expected Behavior

When a MatDialog is opened it should display at the correct size.

#### Actual Behavior

When a MatDialog is opened it displays at an unexpected size, refreshing the screen (Ctrl-F5) fixes the issue i.e. if then displays at the expected size.

More details:
Our testers have reported a strange issue when we publish our documents to sharepoint. We are using a  third party document viewer. After the document is published to sharepoint we lock the document as read only using the third party document viewer. We have raised the issue with the third party supplier but their document viewer is in an iFrame so they don't think it could be causing our issue.

After doing this the user opens another dialog box and it displays at unexpected dimensions. If I refresh the screen, the dialog box, displays at its expected dimensions. See attached 37221.gif. We are using a MatDialog component.

The current width of the dialog box and height is set as a percentage. What I did was to hard code the width, height, min width, max width, min height and max height to be a certain amount of fixed screen pixels like this:
        dialogConfig.width = '1000px';
        dialogConfig.minWidth = '1000px';
        dialogConfig.maxWidth = '1000px';
        dialogConfig.minHeight = '600px';
        dialogConfig.height = '600px';
        dialogConfig.maxHeight = '600px';

I then emptied the dialog box of all content (html) and formatting (css) and repeated the steps. I have left the typescript code for the MatDialog as is, but none of that does anything to the width or height. These are only set when the dialog opens. The dialog box is now blank but the issue still exists. I have attached the video 37721_blank. So I really don't think this is an issue with our code. As per above we don't think it is anything to do with the document viewer. Could the MatDialog itself be causing this issue? How do we fix this?

#### Environment

- Angular: 8.2.14
- Material
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System: When I run locally I use windows. The deployed version runs on Azure. The issue appears on the deployed version and when running locally.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(MatDialog): Displays at a different size but is fixed by screen refresh" (#20524)

Issues.Body:

* Adds the `MatNativeSelectHarness` and `MatNativeOptionHarness` that are used to work with a `select`, marked with `matNativeControl` inside a `mat-form-field`.

Fixes #20005.

Issues.Title: feat(mat-selection-list): Toggle on different event that 'click'
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

Provide the ability to change the "event" that changes the `selected` state of `list-option` component. 

Options I came up with:
* Click - Current behaviour; DEFAULT
* Double click - Self-explanatory; This is what I actually want for my use case
* Keyboard only - Only allow "space" and "enter" to select options

#### Use Case

Sometimes the click event is bound to something else. In my case, I do use currently highlighted row/option as well as checkboxes.

* The highlighted row/option is used to preview the option (image, description, location in the map).
* The checkboxes reflect what the user has selected as viable options for him.

I need to be able to highlight the option on click, but I want to be able to alter the `selected` state via double click.

## Example
I am currently rewriting angularJS app to angular + material. This is the  [angularJS app](https://mapy.agereklama.cz/8670/?h=5E0C7D34143B3F6F8765813E2063E5CD&v=1&c&s=0&l=0&p=0&nl&t=admin#!#115). 

![Image of the app, in case the link would not be online anymore](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2001798/92622349-392dbf80-f2c5-11ea-811e-f8eed8a09d41.png)


The eye in the green list symbolizes the currently selected option. When scrolling through the list you may see that the image above changes, also one of the markers on the map will get a white dot. 

The "checkbox" ("X" or checkmark over small image) tells the user whenever it is the one he wanted or not. On double click, he can toggle the state too.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "feat(mat-selection-list): Toggle on different event that 'click'" (#20520)

Issues.Title: feat(select/testing): Implement harness support for native select
Issues.Body:
Currently we don't have a harness for the native select, we should design a solution for this. It's not entirely clear which harness should be responsible. Some options:
1. `MatSelectHarness` - Seems to be the intuitive place users would think to look, though it may not be feasible to support the full API of `MatSelectHarness` when working with a native select
1. `MatInputHarness` -  Not intuitive for users, but `MatInput` is actually the component that deals with the native select
1. `MatNativeSelectHarness` - Could just make an entirely new harness
1. Don't have a harness for it, but have a better way for the user to get back to working with native elements when necessary (e.g. such as when working with a native select)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "feat(select/testing): Implement harness support for native select" (#20514)

Issues.Title: refactor(overlay): remove deprecated APIs for v11
Issues.Body:
Removes most of the deprecated APIs for v11 under `cdk/overlay`. Note that these changes target primarily the breaking changes that should be easier to land. I've left out removing `ConnectedPositionStrategy` which has a separate PR (#17519), and `GlobalPositionStrategy.width` and `GlobalPositionStrategy.height`, because they'll be trickier to land.

BREAKING CHANGES:
* The `OVERLAY_PROVIDERS` constant has been removed. Import `OverlayModule` and use the providers directly instead.
* `_platform` parameter of the `OverlayContainer` constructor is now required.
* `_platform` parameter of the `FullscreenOverlayContainer` constructor is now required.
* `_location` and `_outsideClickDispatcher` parameters of the `OverlayRef` constructor are now required.
* `_location` and `_outsideClickDispatcher` parameters of the `Overlay` constructor are now required.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(overlay): remove deprecated APIs for v11" (#20511)
